title: Energy and pd - particle at -10V goes to plus 10V

content.question: A negatively charged particle moving in an electric field is initially at an electric potential of <math alttext="negative 10 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math> and moving in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. A short time later, the particle is located at an electric potential of <math alttext="positive 10 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math> and still moving in the same direction. Which of the following statements describes the change in electrical potential energy of the particle-field system as the particle moves from a <math alttext="negative 10 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math> to a <math alttext="positive 10 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math> potential, and provides evidence or reasoning that supports the claim?

choices.label: The change in electrical potential energy is zero. The direction of the particleâ€™s motion does not change.
The change in electrical potential energy is zero. The final electric potential has the same absolute value as the initial electric potential.
The change is electrical potential energy is negative. The initial electric potential is negative.
The change in electrical potential energy is negative. The final electric potential is higher than the initial electric potential, and the particle has a negative charge.

content.answer: The change in electrical potential energy is negative. The final electric potential is higher than the initial electric potential, and the particle has a negative charge.
